article.headline: Lady Lions answer halftime call
article.linkText: Under pressure: Penn State wins with D
article.story:
INDIANAPOLIS (AP) -- Penn State turned up the pressure on
Indiana, and again, the Hoosiers couldn't handle it.

Kelly Mazzante scored 25 points, Tanisha Wright had 22 points
and six rebounds and the fifth-ranked Nittany Lions used a strong
second-half defensive surge to get past Indiana 79-66 in the Big
Ten tournament quarterfinals.

"It was a defensive plea," Penn State coach Rene Portland said
of her halftime speech. "We weren't playing very smart."

Message received.

The Nittany Lions used their relentless full-court pressure to
rattle the Hoosiers, and the few times that didn't work, their
in-your-face defense ruined Indiana's half-court sets.

The result was almost a carbon copy of the first meeting between
the teams, when the Hoosiers made mistake after mistake and lost
66-49.

This time, the strategy sent Penn State (24-4), the Big Ten
regular-season champs and top seed, into Sunday's semifinal game
against No. 25 Michigan State, an 81-54 winner over Iowa.

There are no games Saturday because the Indiana high school
girls state championships will be played at Conseco Fieldhouse.

Indiana (12-17) was led by Cyndi Valentin's 18 points, and Jenny
DeMuth, who had 17 points and nine rebounds. But it wasn't enough
to avoid ending their season with 10 losses in 12 games or getting
eliminated by Penn State in the quarterfinals for the second
straight year.

"They're a pressure team and we knew they would come at us,"
Valentin said. "I think we could have handled it better."

Wright, the Big Ten's two-time defensive player of the year, was
the catalyst.

She carried Penn State's sluggish offense in the first half by
scoring 15 points, then changed the game in the second half.

Her quick steal and layup to open the second half set the tone.
Another steal and a quick pass to Mazzante for a layup got the
Nittany Lions' scoring leader warmed up and then it was all over.

Indiana coach Kathi Bennett knew almost instantly it was
trouble.

"They are a really, really good team and when they decide to
put pressure on you, you need to be really, really good," Bennett
said.

The Hoosiers weren't, and it showed.

When Penn State went to its full-court pressure to start the
second half, Indiana started playing like the nation's
fourth-youngest team by making a series of mistakes.

DeMuth grabbed the rebound off an errant Penn State shot on the
opening possession, but Wright swiped it away and put in the layup.

Then, with Penn State leading 44-40 with 15:46 remaining, the
Nittany Lions trapped Valentin in the corner, forcing a time out.
After drawing up a play, Wright again stole the ball and hit an
open Mazzante for the layup.

That ignited 10-2 run during the next 1:46, which gave the
Nittany Lions a 54-42 lead.

Wright also finished with five assists and four steals.

It was only the start.

After Valentin drove in for a layup to make it 56-46, Penn State
ran off seven straight points and it was game over.

Mazzante scored 18 of her points in the second half and passed
Mercer's Andrea Congreaves for 11th place on the NCAA's career
scoring list. Mazzante has scored 2,820 points in her career.

But even Mazzante admitted defense that won this game.

"We were taking stupid chances and they were hitting wide open
3s," Mazzante said of the Hoosiers. "In the second half we came
out and attacked more, and we controlled the tempo, as we usually
do."
